explanation:
For checking compliance with the MISRA rule banning language/compiler extensions we must inspect macros, typedefs, wrappers and conditional compile flags that could expand to or enable compiler-specific constructs. Brief reasons per symbol:

- _MHD_EXTERN: controls function linkage/visibility; commonly defined as __declspec(...) or __attribute__((visibility(...))) — explicit compiler extensions may be used here.
- mhd_assert: assertion macro often expands to branch/diagnostic code; may use __builtin_unreachable, __attribute__, or other compiler built-ins — need its definition.
- MHD_PANIC: panic/report macro may use non-standard extensions (attributes, builtins, inline asm) or call __builtin_unreachable — inspect it.
- _: (gettext macro) used around string literals; its definition could be a macro/function mapping that uses extensions or attributes — check it.
- MHD_INVALID_SOCKET: sentinel constant/macro; its definition may be platform-specific (e.g. -1 or INVALID_SOCKET) and could hide platform-specific extension usage.
- MHD_socket: typedef/alias for socket type; may be mapped to platform-specific types (e.g. SOCKET on Windows) that come with macros or extension-like usage.
- MHD_itc_activate_, MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_ITC_IS_INVALID_: inter-thread-communication helpers/macros; their implementations or macros may use compiler built-ins or inline asm — inspect.
- MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_, MHD_thread_handle_ID_join_thread_: thread-handle wrappers may hide platform-specific constructs or compiler extensions (e.g. __attribute__ usage, compiler-specific thread APIs).
- MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_, MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_: predicate macros that may be implemented with compiler-specific expressions or attributes; also control code paths that might contain extensions.
- MHD_socket_close_chk_, MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_: wrapper helpers that may use compiler extensions (attributes, builtins) for checking/annotations; inspect definitions.
- close_all_connections: called from MHD_stop_daemon and the call graph shows it calls __builtin_unreachable; need its body to see if an extension is used there or via macros it uses.
- __builtin_unreachable: GCC/clang builtin is an explicit language extension. Presence in macros or callees must be detected; check if any macros expand to calls to this builtin.
- MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS, MHD_USE_W32_THREADS, HAVE_LISTEN_SHUTDOWN, EPOLL_SUPPORT, HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT, DAUTH_SUPPORT: these compile-time feature macros control which code paths are compiled. To be sure no extension is used in any active or alternative path, their definitions/values must be known so you can inspect the relevant branches and macros used under those configurations.

In short: inspect all macro/typedef/function definitions listed above (and the body of close_all_connections) to detect use of compiler built-ins (like __builtin_*), attributes (__attribute__, __declspec), inline asm, or other documented compiler extensions. Only those definitions determine whether the target function or any code it depends on uses language extensions.
